title: Hollywood sees the light; admits, "maybe we should start making better movies"
body:
I'm sure this article isn't indicative of how everyone feels in Hollywood, but it's one of the first optimistic pieces I've read about the decline in theater attendence. The article is written by Lynda Obst, who produced such money-making films as FLASHDANCE, ADVENTURES IN BABYSITTING, SLEEPLESS IN SEATTLE, and most recently, HOW TO LOSE A GUY IN 10 DAYS. I thought you guys might enjoy reading it, and have a comment or two about the conclusion.

We Lost It at the Movies
author: Dan

comments.author: Caleb
comments.body: Very interesting read...thanks for linking it. It's actually quite handy, as I'm writing a research paper about box office trends in recent years and it will be an excellent source.

comments.author: bjork24
comments.body: Next time you work, remind me to loan you our Theater Owner's Almanac... it's filled with graphs on box office stuff.

comments.author: Jordan
comments.body:
THAT'LL keep 'em from making another "Big Momma's House".

...I hope.

comments.author: Nate
comments.body:
That article was one big DUH.

How much are these movie producers making again?

comments.author: Derek
comments.body: I enjoyed it immensely. Thanks. It's nice to see that producers are starting to realize what they need to do to keep us happy. However, as a teenage boy I saw most of the movies she mentioned as being successful for baby boomers and thought they were fantastic. Weird.

comments.author: Master RJ
comments.body: Pure and simple, we need more revenge films films for adults and less CGI, horrible acting, Akiva Goldsman and big budgets.

comments.author: bjork24
comments.body: In other words, more Audrey Tautou, less Clea DuVall.

comments.author: Nate
comments.body: Audrey Tautou has been immersed in her share of digital color enhancement.

comments.author: Nicole
comments.body: I'm looking forward to Russian Dolls (with Audrey Tautou) later this summer!

comments.author: Master RJ
comments.body: Actually, Clea DuVall's not that bad, she just needs more good parts like "Thirteen Conversations About One Thing" and less bad parts like "The Faculty" (I hated that movie) and "The Grudge".

comments.author: Caleb
comments.body: Hey now, don't knock Akiva. Despite the crap he's given us in the past (Batman Forever, Batman & Robin, Lost in Space, I,Robot...), he did give us A Beautiful Mind and Cinderella Man. Then again, it's obvious that he's powerless without Ron Howard.

comments.author: Master RJ
comments.body: A Beautiful Mind was seeminging Akiva's only good script. In the rest, he obviously does not know what a supporting character is or when to end a scene (Cough, Mr. and Mrs. Smith, a film co-written by him and his protege, Simon Frickin' Kinberg, along with fifty others. Both of them shall be caught for crimes against humanity.)
